Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Coral Reef Biodiversity and Resilience on Little Cayman
Award.AbstractNarration: Coral reefs maintain the highest biological diversity in the ocean and are also among the most threatened ecosystems on earth. This award provides funding for a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the Central Caribbean Marine Institute (CCMI) located on Little Cayman Islands. The CCMI REU program will provide a unique opportunity for 24 undergraduate students over three years to explore fundamental ecological processes critical to maintaining coral reef biodiversity and resilience. Participating students will have a rare opportunity to conduct research on a small remote Caribbean island with low local development pressure. Coral reefs at this site are recovering from the 1998 El Nino event during which high sea surface temperatures killed corals on a global scale. The processes that are driving this recovery are still unknown. Therefore, this REU affords rich and timely opportunities to closely examine ecosystem stress and recovery from a number of perspectives. The multidisciplinary team of scientific mentors included in this REU are researching topics aimed at understanding global and local threats from climate change and ocean acidification (OA), and physical, chemical, and ecological disturbances on coral reefs. Experiments and field work examining fundamental organismal, community and ecosystem functions will be integral to this research. The research conducted by REU undergraduate participants will advance our knowledge of the processes that drive coral reef resilience to disturbances on multiple spatial and temporal scales. Co-funding for this award is provided by the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coral Reef Biodiversity and Resilience Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the Central Caribbean Marine Institute (CCMI) is located on Little Cayman, in the Cayman Islands. This programe involved an immersive international research component combined with professional development opportunities for eight undergraduate students each year from 2014 – 2016. The CCMI REU program established important pathways for undergraduate students to gain valuable experience and advance their future integration into research, graduate programs, and scientific careers. The program was run through the CCMI Little Cayman Research Centre (LCRC), which provides a residential field station experience where both mentors and students live and work together. CCMI mentors offered significant opportunities for student advancement across three major research themes that are relevant to both society and the conservation of coral reef ecosystems: 1) climate change and ocean acidification; 2) ecological processes and resilience; and 3) geology and paleoclimatology.

The CCMI REU offered students exposure to both applied and blue sky science projects, which provided an excellent platform for students to consider career paths in either academia, government, or industry. Students had the opportunity to work in a facility that houses fully equipped wet, dry and climate-controlled laboratories as well as out in the field both terrestrially and marine via SCUBA and snorkel.  Students gained experience and worked independently through an internal “peer” review process which aided project planning, design, and progress.

Mentors hosted weekly workshops that developed and honed the scientific and analytical skills of the REU students, including: statistics, software specific for community analysis of coral reefs, underwater field research methods, and laboratory techniques. Workshops were also hosted to provide insight into establishing a career in science including, graduate school applications, creating academic profiles, and scientific networking.  In addition, scientific presentations from several local )Department of Environment government agency) and international scientists occurred throughout programs on a variety of research topics. 

                  Five REU interns have returned to CCMI in 2016-2017 to continue their independent research for subsequent publication and presentation, as summer interns or as research staff members. Of the 2014-2015 Little Cayman REU alumni, 87.5% are currently working in STEM-related fields or pursuing graduate degrees (data from 2016 is under review). All of our students are encouraged to present their research at scientific conferences.  In total, 19 of our 2014-2016 REU alumni have or will be giving 25 poster or oral presentations at 14 scientific conferences. Conference posters may be viewed online at http://reefresearch.org/publications/conference/.  Scientific findings have spanned a wide array of topic areas including local coral reef ecology, the impact of climate variability on local reef resilience, impacts and patterns of sea turtle grazing, parrotfish diet and their importance to reef health, management and behavior of the invasive lionfish, and the geological history of Little Cayman. To date, three peer review publications have been produced from this research with additional papers in preparation.

Broader impacts of the eight-week program included participation in the CCMI science to society outreach initiative. Through this initiative, REU participants had the opportunity to share their findings with non-scientific audiences in informal presentation settings as a part of CCMI’s Reef Lecture Series given each week at a local resort. The REU student’s involvement with the science to society outreach initiative also included: participation in the weekly (community) Reef Lecture Series, beach clean-ups, sea turtle nest monitoring and hatchling releases with the Department of Environment (DOE), assisting with local projects to remove invasive terrestrial (Green Iguana) and marine (lionfish) species.

 

For specific questions or comments about this information including the NSF Project Outcomes Report, contact us.
